text:
*[Bug 18934] New: Improve computing of Kendall's tau in stats::cor()*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18934>

            Bug ID: 18934
           Summary: Improve computing of Kendall's tau in stats::cor()
           Product: R
           Version: R 4.5.x
          Hardware: Other
                OS: Other
            Status: UNCONFIRMED
          Severity: enhancement
          Priority: P5
         Component: Analyses
          Assignee: <mailto:R-core@R-project.org|R-core@R-project.org>
          Reporter: <mailto:ht@heatherturner.net|ht@heatherturner.net>

Originally proposed as an R Dev Day issue by Kurt Hornik, this turned out to be
larger in scope, so adding as a potential HELP WANTED item.

## Background

The code in stats::cor() for computing Kendall's tau has runtime $O(n^2)$ where
$O(n\log(n))$ is possible via the algorithm used by `pcaPP::<http://cor.fk|cor.fk>` (originally
proposed by Knight (1966), see `?pcaPP::<http://cor.fk|cor.fk>` for more recent references).
As Kurt said: "it would be nice in the modern times of big data to improve
stats::cor() to also employ the better algorithm". 

## Current status

Despite the file name (`cov.kendall.cpp`) and Boost C++ license, Dirk
Eddelbuettel and Aymeric Stamm confirmed that the code in the pcaPP package is
plain C. It seems the C code was written by David Simcha and offered on the
R-devel mailing list back in 2010
(<https://stat.ethz.ch/pipermail/r-devel/2010-February/056745.html>). David
identified the real challenge as integrating this code with the code in
`stats/src/cov.c`, as this code "intermingles computing Kendall's Tau with
dealing with missing values and computing other kinds of correlation".

text:
*[Bug 18935] New: Typo in vowels table in character.c file*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18935>

            Bug ID: 18935
           Summary: Typo in vowels table in character.c file
           Product: R
           Version: R-devel (trunk)
          Hardware: All
                OS: All
            Status: UNCONFIRMED
          Severity: trivial
          Priority: P5
         Component: Misc
          Assignee: <mailto:R-core@R-project.org|R-core@R-project.org>
          Reporter: <mailto:lukasz.daniel@gmail.com|lukasz.daniel@gmail.com>

In character.c, line 828, 3rd character ("0x2e") is a typo. It should have been
"0xe2".
```
x2e in ASCII is a dot (".").
xe2 is "a" with circumflex

```

Target vowels table should look like:
```
static int vowels[] = {
    0x61, 0x65, 0x69, 0x6f, 0x75, // a, e, i, o, u
    0xe0, 0xe1, 0xe2, 0xe3, 0xe4, 0xe5,// a variants
    0xe8, 0xe9, 0xea, 0xeb, 0xec, 0xed, 0xee, 0xef, // e, i variants
    0xf2, 0xf3, 0xf4, 0xf5, 0xf6, 0xf8, 0xf9, 0xfa, 0xfb, 0xfc, // o, u
variants
    0x101, 0x103, 0x105, 0x113, 0x115, 0x117, 0x118, 0x11b, // a, e variants
    0x129, 0x12b, 0x12d, 0x12f, 0x131, 0x14d, 0x14f, 0x151, // i, o variants
    0x169, 0x16b, 0x16d, 0x16f, 0x171, 0x173 // u variants
};
```

text:
*[Bug 16659] match.arg with several.ok silently ignores incorrect arguments as long as there is one valid argument.*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=16659>

Martin Maechler (<mailto:maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch|maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CONFIRMED
                 CC|                            |maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch
     Ever confirmed|0                           |1

--- Comment #1 from Martin Maechler (<mailto:maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch|maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch>) ---
Getting back to this.  The current default semantic of `several.ok = TRUE`  had
been set quite on purpose,  when I created it, and I think it could well be
quite disruptive to change it now.
From grepping a bit in my own and other's CRAN package I've seen quite a few
usages which looked to me the authors really wanting "filter" the matching
options and not be concerned about the non-matching ones. 

However I see your point and wish that a such a `match.arg(..)` option could be
useful and possibly be used quite frequently, instead of the current
`several.ok=TRUE` setting.

To do so is quite simple as you mentioned the simple  `s/all/any/` change.

Let's consider how the UI could / should look like.

1. One possibility would be a simple new logical argument, e.g.,  `all.match =
FALSE` (default) where `all.match = TRUE` would provide the new behaviour.

2. Another possibility would be to allow the existing argument `several.ok` to
take on new possible values, e.g,
   a) in addition to {FALSE, TRUE} it could also be a string such as
`"match_all"` 
   b) or we could use the 3rd logical value, `NA`, to mean that which would be
pure" in requiring a logical scalar (but  clearly less self-explaining as it
seems not at all obvious to me or another code reader what  `several.ok = NA`
should mean).

Other opinions / comments / tastes ?

text:
*[Bug 18936] New: Implement `chkDots()`'s `allowed` argument*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18936>

            Bug ID: 18936
           Summary: Implement `chkDots()`'s `allowed` argument
           Product: R
           Version: R-devel (trunk)
          Hardware: All
                OS: All
            Status: UNCONFIRMED
          Severity: minor
          Priority: P5
         Component: Language
          Assignee: <mailto:R-core@R-project.org|R-core@R-project.org>
          Reporter: <mailto:trevor.l.davis@gmail.com|trevor.l.davis@gmail.com>

Created attachment 3527
  --> <https://bugs.r-project.org/attachment.cgi?id=3527&action=edit>
Implement the `allowed` argument of `chkDots()`

`chkDots()` has a documented not yet implemented `allowed` argument.  This
patch implements this `allowed` argument and adds several tests to
`reg-tests-1e.R`.  Currently the patch also adds a `chkDotsWarning` subclass to
the emitted warning so it would be easier to either selectively ignore it or
escalate it to an error.

I observe at least one case on Github where a developer would have used
`chkDots()` if the `allowed` argument had been implemented:
<https://github.com/skyelong/pavo/blob/23c370823c8529c2875f025b21e69e1fc8a37eeb/R/merge.rspec.R#L30>

text:
*[Bug 18937] New: unclear status of group generic function 'matrixOps'*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18937>

            Bug ID: 18937
           Summary: unclear status of group generic function 'matrixOps'
           Product: R
           Version: R-devel (trunk)
          Hardware: Other
                OS: Other
            Status: UNCONFIRMED
          Severity: normal
          Priority: P5
         Component: Documentation
          Assignee: <mailto:R-core@R-project.org|R-core@R-project.org>
          Reporter: <mailto:jaganmn@mcmaster.ca|jaganmn@mcmaster.ca>

`help("crossprod")` says:

> These are generic functions since R 4.4.0: methods can be written individually or via the `matOps` group generic function; it dispatches to S3 and S4 methods.

Ignoring the typo `s/matOps/matrixOps/`, the sentence seems to claim that
`crossprod` and `tcrossprod` dispatch both S3 methods and S4 methods for
`matrixOps`.  That's currently not true.

```
> .S3method("matrixOps", "zzz3", function (x, y) "ok")
> setClass("zzz4", contains = "numeric")
> setMethod("matrixOps", c(x = "zzz4", y = "missing"), function (x, y) "ok")
> x3 <- `class<-`(0, "zzz3")
> x4 <- new("zzz4")
> crossprod(x3)
[1] "ok"
> crossprod(x4)
     [,1]
[1,]    0
> tcrossprod(x3)
[1] "ok"
> tcrossprod(x4)
<0 x 0 matrix>
```

So `crossprod` and `tcrossprod` dispatch S3 methods for `matrixOps` but not S4
methods for `matrixOps`.  That is consistent with:

```
> getGroupMembers("matrixOps")
[1] "%*%"
```

If it has been intended since R 4.4 that they would dispatch S4 methods for
`matrixOps`, too, then maybe such a change should happen for R 4.6 ... ?

One last discrepancy: `help("S3groupGeneric")` says:

> This group currently contains the matrix multiply `%*%` binary operator only, where at least `crossprod()` and `tcrossprod()` are meant to follow.

It seems that `crossprod` and `tcrossprod` have *already* followed, if both
dispatch S3 methods for `matrixOps`, hence perhaps this sentence should be
amended now.

In contrast, `help("S4groupGeneric")` seems correct for now, but it would have
to be amended, too, should `crossprod` and `tcrossprod` start dispatching S4
methods for `matrixOps`.

text:
*[Bug 18937] unclear status of group generic function 'matrixOps'*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18937>

Kurt Hornik (<mailto:Kurt.Hornik@wu.ac.at|Kurt.Hornik@wu.ac.at>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |Kurt.Hornik@wu.ac.at

--- Comment #1 from Kurt Hornik (<mailto:Kurt.Hornik@wu.ac.at|Kurt.Hornik@wu.ac.at>) ---
For the record, I have been arguing that it would be preferable not to have
matrix products in a new group, but instead use left to right internal dispatch
as we do for rbind and cbind (and maybe provide a general interface for doing
this).
Otherwise, if e.g package A provides a sparse matrix class cA and package B
provides a sparse matrix class cB it is impossible to conveniently arrange for
the appropriate dispatch when doing a matrix product of cA x and cB y.
(If both A and B provide matrixOps methods, neither will be dispatched to.)
I still think this is what we should change to, perhaps with the matrixOps
dispatch as fallback.

as we do for rbind and cbind (and maybe provide a general interface for doing
this).
Otherwise, if e.g package A provides a sparse matrix class cA and package B
provides a sparse matrix class cB it is impossible to conveniently arrange for
the appropriate dispatch when doing a matrix product of cA x and cB y.
(If both A and B provide matrixOps methods, neither will be dispatched to.)
I still think this is what we should change to, perhaps with the matrixOps
dispatch as fallback.
